turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well, the -- both the -- the testimony before Congress was an -- there's an indication.
People have stated that the customer tends to throw away the tag and the invoice is something that she tends to keep.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, was the test -- well, that there was testimony that's something that she tends to keep?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Justice.
We have set that out at pages 19 and 25 --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, is this something peculiar to the purchase of furs?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Perhaps, and that it tends to be a major item of purchase and the information with respect to the furs, something the average housewife, I think, would be more likely to keep.
The -- at least that seems to be the evidence was before Congress.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did the Court of Appeals take judicial knowledge of why it did not keep those things?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: No, Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Did it take judicial knowledge as they did?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: No, they just took judicial knowledge of the -- based to this definition of invoice.
They didn't -- they didn't go into considerations of the purpose.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Your argument is that the evidence before Congress showed there was a difference?
And they did show that they wanted to and that the Court ought not to change, is that --

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That is correct, Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What is the evidence, in any report or in the spokesman of the bill?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: No, the evidence is in --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Both by congressmen or witnesses in hearings.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Witnesses at hearings before the congressional committees.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And what were their qualifications?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: They were representatives of the fur industry.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And they wanted this statute to be -- must be a noble industry.
I must say they wanted --

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: No, Mr. Justice -- no, Mr. Justice, they certainly did not want this statute.
They opposed it.
But they suggested that if Congress felt that some protection was needed for the consumer, adequate protection would be given through the invoice in requirement, give the consumer the invoice.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Now Mr. Friedman then, is it -- am I correct in thinking that the material set out on -- in your brief in which invoices are so highly allotted by representatives of the industry.
The fact is that they were proposing invoices instead of labels, isn't that correct?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: They weren't comparing invoices to labels.
They wished -- they -- they were opposing labels, isn't that right?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: They -- they were -- they were suggesting that an invoice was superior to --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Was sufficient?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That's right, but the statue as -- that it came out of Congress, provided poor labeling and we think in the circumstances, it would have been anomalous that Congress gave them the greater protection, apparently, what they seem to think of the label and at the same time, denied in the protection of the invoice.
I made --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And they will also have the price?
This is what you call the label.
Does that have the price of the fur?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Presumably, it's not required.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But -- but at -- as industry practice, doesn't the label have the price?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Yes, but that would have to be on the other side of the label under the Commission's rules, only certain information can be set forth on one side of the label, the required information.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: May I ask what -- what objection the Mandel offered to this?
What -- what objection did he have to do in this, to that fur, did they say?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Well, their -- their objection was -- they said the Act is not applicable to the retail merchant.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: They said it was not applicable to a retail merchant.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: The false invoicing provisions.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, did the court below hold that?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: The court below held that the false invoicing provisions are not applicable to retails --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: To retail merchant?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: To retail merchant, that's correct.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: Can that be sold upon (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That seems to be the opinion of the Court, it just looks -- as we read the opinion, it just looked to the particular language.
I would now briefly like to turn to the --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Before -- may I ask one more question.

Am I right in understanding that this is not a case where the so-called invoice, when I say so-called, not in an invidious way, this technical invoice was stated things falsely, just didn't state what was required by -- under your views of the statute, is that right?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: This isn't a case where an invoice misrepresented.
It didn't make the representations, which according to your views are affirmatively required.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That is correct, but the -- where the statute says that something --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I -- I understand that.
I just want --

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: In my mind, there might be a difference where a piece of paper is given which -- which misrepresents, is underrepresented, is that it?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That it fails to represent.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Failed to represent.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Briefly to turn to the second issue in the case, which is --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Is there any -- this is just an order so that we're not bothered here where the mens rea is required.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: No, this is a cease-and-desist -- this statute requires without any mens rea certain obligations.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did they put in the label to in evidence?
Did it come in evidence?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Yes, the labels are set forth at 64 (a) and 66 (b) of the record.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: That -- the labels I saw didn't state much statement.
You -- you mean that's a sample of blank label.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That is a sample of the label and 66 (b) is another label stating that the country of origin of the fur and stating that it's mink.
Our -- our --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: And that does contain all the information you say it should.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Perhaps.
I don't know as to this particular label, but the complaint against them is they failed to state certain information such as the fur was dyed and properly, the state (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, is that on their label?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: That's required both on the label.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Did they state all the information on the label?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: No, they didn't.
That -- and that comes to the scope of the second part of the case.
The order against misbranding, the statute requires that to be -- avoid being misbranded, the label must contain six categories of information specified.

The Commission in this case found that the label failed to include three categories of information and further found there was no evidence that the label failed to include the other categories of information.
The Commission entered an order directing them to cease-and-desist from misbranding by failing to include on their label, the six categories of information specifying these six categories.

The Court of Appeal struck from the order against mislabeling, the provisions covering the three categories of information with respect to which the Commission found there was no evidence or violation.

Now, at the outset, I may say that the principal complaint of Mandel against this phase of the order is its fear that the public will get the misapprehension that by virtue of having been told to cease-and-desist from this other violations that somehow violated them.

And in their brief at page 40, they have suggested -- perhaps suggested that an alternative form of order, which will not specify the particular subcategories but will merely state to cease-and-desist from failing to include all the information required by the statute.
And in a brief -- reply brief, we have stated that we construe that as having the same effect as the Commission's order.
We therefore do not object to the form.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Friedman, there -- there are two phrases or -- or two words that are used in this case that bothered me a little, one of them is invoice and I'd like to know if there's anything in the record to indicate that the term “invoice” is or is not used in the retail trade as it is in the wholesale trade.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: The legislative history speak -- speak --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You -- you take it off from the legislative history.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Yes.
There's nothing in the record --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: -- in this case as such in which the word invoice is used in the retail trade other than the statutory definition of invoice.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: But the --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right, go ahead.

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: The legislative history does show that they referred to the need for an invoice to a retail consumer, at least the fur representatives at that time were using the term “invoice” as applicable to retail sale, the retail sales slip.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Now, is there anything in the record that would indicate whether the term “commercial transaction” is used by Congress in connection with retail transactions as well as wholesale transactions?

turn.speaker: daniel_m_friedman
turn.label: Mr. Daniel M. Friedman
turn.text: Again, Mr. Chief Justice, nothing in the record.
But in the legislative history, there is repeated reference to the need to protect consumers among other things against -- to set what we think deceptive invoice.
And then we therefore draw from the legislative history the inference that Congress used “commercial transaction” to include the sale by the commercial retailer to the individual customer.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Thank you.
Mr. Horne.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, if the Court please.
To answer one or two of the questions at the outset, Mr. Justice Black asked what will Mandel do about invoicing.
Mandel gave invoices.

There are some two or three samples of them in the -- in the record at page 65, 66 -- 66 (a) the -- the problem is whether the statute specifies what has to be on those invoices to the retail consumer, but it -- it isn't a matter of resisting, the giving of -- of an invoice.
It's a question of whether we are at that point subject to the act's invoicing requirements.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You do consider this in the trade as an invoice, the -- the document which appears at 66 (a).

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: I'm not sure, Your Honor, that we do.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, you just said -- you just said they did.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Well, we're using invoice here.
I suppose I as a term of art, we're talking about a statute which requires invoicing.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Now, whether this is an invoice in the retail trade, there's nothing in the record about that, one way or the other.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, just an ordinary sales slip.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: I beg your pardon?

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: It's just the ordinary sales slip.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: That's the way we -- we view it.
It was in this FTC proceeding, treated as an invoice within the Act and the complaint there didn't comply.
But --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But is the real question whether, although it is an ordinary sales slip thing, you and I or -- or I and my ignorance, my -- my extreme of calling it an invoice, Congress is entitled to give invoice defined -- limit beyond the colloquial meaning.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Well, that's right, it is.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And the question is whether it has done so.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: That -- that brings us down to the -- to the heart of the question.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Certainly.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Whether in specifying the invoicing, Congress brought within its scope these invoices that are given at the -- at the retail level.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, now -- now may I -- may I ask this.
Do you concede that the -- that the term “invoice” is a -- an appropriate term and is used in the retail business?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: If Your Honor please, in the early -- early in briefing stages, as I recall, we raised the point and went on.
But an invoice in the common concept of the term isn't the sort of thing that you get when you brought to the counter and buy something and get a sales slip.
That is used at different stages of a commercial process.

But in this prosecution, if you turn the -- generally, we -- we were faced with the contention that that sales slip is the invoice that Congress talked about and that it didn't comply so we had to make the issue on that point.
I still adhere to my basic feeling that an invoice happens at a different stage in the commercial process.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: When you say you have to meet the issue, other than saying it isn't an invoice in the terms of the statute.
What do you mean by that?
How did you -- how do you meet it except in that way?
You mean allege you did -- you don't meet it by --

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Well, we --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- to satisfy the requirement if this be an invoice, did it?
It did not satisfy the requirement.
If this be a statutory --

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: That --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- of why invoice, it didn't satisfy --

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: That came to be one of the questions in the case that --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But you say you had to meet the issue --

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Whether --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: What?
I don't understand that.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: We had to face up to the issue, perhaps, I should have said.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: But what was -- how do you face up to it except by saying --

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Where -- well --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: -- you're not within the statute?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: First, we denied that it was an -- an invoice within the statute.
Furthermore, we contended that such invoices as had been presented in the proceeding did comply.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: I see.
That's (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: And --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: That's what I was searching for.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: It was found that some of them lacked, some of the required -- some of the elements, some of the representations that would be required if it were a statutory invoice within the Act.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Let me be clear about this.
There was -- this is a piece of paper, it contains certain writings, certain information.

If you were to agree that you do not, that the statute required you for this transaction to comply with the statute, did it contain the information that the statute command be contained in such a piece of paper?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Speaking of the sales slips that are in evidence here.
The finding was that some of them lacked one or more of the six required elements.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Well now, if you -- if you are required to include those elements, then the Commission has a right to issue this into this order, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: And so I go back to my question.
Are you contending that even though this be considered an invoice within the terms of the statute, you comply with what was required?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: On the invoicing issue, I think that we are concluded by the finding below that --

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: There were omissions -- there were omissions.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: They were -- there were omissions.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: But the Court of Appeals did agree with your fundamental and primary contention that these were not invoices within the meaning of the statute, is that (Voice Overlap)?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And that's the issue here on that -- on that part of the case, isn't that it?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: That is the -- that is the first issue, whether those invoices, good or bad, or the in -- or the invoices contemplated by the statute, in the private statute.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: If that's not an invoice, what would be invoice?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: What would be an invoice?
I should say that the term "in common acceptance" is used when the manufacturer ships a batch of stuff to a wholesaler or to a retailer.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You mean the retailer cannot issue an invoice.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Technically, he can, but I'm saying that in the common acceptance of the term and whether Congress --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I'm -- I'm -- what I'm -- I might -- you say that this fee were not invoice, isn't what I ask you on -- if these are not invoices, how could a retailer issue an invoice?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: I -- I'd have difficulty in saying how a retailer could invoice, I --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Your -- your position seems to me to be that the retailer can't do it.
Suppose I'd go into sales rulebook and buy it for the argument.
They write them all down in one thing and that is to me not -- is that an invoice?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: If we are wrong on this first issue here, it is.
But I'm -- I still feel that in --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, that in your -- in your judgment, would that be an invoice?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: In --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Hold on -- hold on to invoice 12 different furs, put them all down just what they have here.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: In your judgment, would that be an invoice via retail?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: An invoice is usually defined as a list of goods sent together with prices perhaps from one person to another.
Well, that's a -- that's a broad general term.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Whole -- wholesales -- wholesales over put down on here and I went in and bought 15 furs and put them all down, put down the price on each.
In your judgment, would that be an invoice within the meaning of this statute?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Within the meaning of the statute to -- no, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, if not, what could be an invoice?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Well, an invoice within the meaning of the statute is one thing and an invoice --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: What could be --

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: -- at large --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: In your judgment, are you saying that a retailer cannot issue an invoice?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: I don't --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Something he does would be an invoice.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: I don't believe we can say that.
No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, what would be then if this is --

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: This technically --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I'm not talking about this.
Well, what would be an invoice?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Technically, this may be an invoice at large.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: In your judgment, (Voice Overlap) invoice, under the statute if this is one.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Technically, this may be, speaking at large and apart from the statute, these sales slips may be invoices too.
But the question is whether --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Maybe.
If they're not invoices, how could the retailer give an invoice?
Maybe they can, I'm not saying that -- I just don't know.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Well, I -- my difficulty is in getting away from the strong feeling that in -- in the common acceptance of the term, an invoice is an earlier stage of the process.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Earlier stage, you mean --

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Prior to the retailers' handling.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: In other words, a retailer doesn't issue invoice.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Not in the common acceptance of the term, but I don't believe, Your Honor, that with all respect that that's going to -- to get us anywhere because we've got a definition of invoice here.
And the question is whether what they did was within -- or whether that step -- step of the process is within the statutory definition of invoice.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You mean by saying step, when the retailer does?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Does the -- yes, sir.
Yes, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: You are thinking of invoices given by manufactures or wholesales.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: I think that's -- that is certainly the common acceptance of the term and that is the way we view the requirements.
That's correct.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Horne, let's take this situation.
I notice in the -- in the record that Mandel Brothers do a lot of other state business too.
That is people come to this store and -- and have a good shipped out of the State.

Suppose they ship this -- this fur that we're talking about from -- from Chicago to New York, and send it C.O.D. to the customer, and they issued some kind of a -- of a document to indicate what the price was and what the article was and so forth, what would you call that?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Perhaps we'd have to call that a non-statutory invoice, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: [Laughter]

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: How do you use the word "invoice"?

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: [Laughs] No, we were labeling this from a -- the carrier.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Well, of course.
The -- the obstacle in many of these considerations is the limited nature of the statutory definition.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Where -- what part of the statute is that you think States takes out of retailer?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Two parts, Your Honor, which is issued in connection with any commercial dealing --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: In what ways to stop right then and do you consider this a commercial dealing?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: The sale from the -- from Mandel to -- to the customer?

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: It seems to me that dealing imports two people.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Well, there are two here.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: And dealing commercially imports trafficking in goods with a view to resale or exchange as a business.

And unless you have on both sides of your transaction, your retailer and your -- your customer if the customer is buying to sell to someone else, that's one thing but if -- that is not the ordinary situation.

That imports, it seems to me, that first commercial clause, the necessity of their being of persons on each side of the transaction that are trafficking for gain, dealing commercially then now, the second clause --

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I imagine both of these are, one of them is trying to get as cheap as it can, which is -- I'm afraid my recent experience, they -- they will not achieve and the other is trying to get as much profit as they can get.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: I suspect in this situation --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: May I ask you (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: If --

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Well, may I -- continue to answer your question first, please?

The other clause in the definition and the -- the one that's been more talked about is purchaser, consignee and so on, or any other person who is engaged in dealing commercially in fur product or furs.
Now, that's a big mouthful.
I think it might help get that picture if we say transported or delivered to a purchaser and so on, or any other commercially dealing person.
To shorten the -- the -- who is dealing?

That clearly, it seems to us, requires that the transferee in the process, the recipient of the statutory invoice, be a person who is dealing commercially, the Court of Appeals took both clauses, one as reinforcing the other.
But it seems to us that either clause would exclude from the purview of invoice as defined in the Act and that fall from the invoice in the requirements, the retail sale to the consumer.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Sometimes a consumer turns out to be a seller himself, wouldn't it?
When installment, they come around.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: That sometimes is the case.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: I can't get -- I couldn't draw this line.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Well, if you have -- if you simply draw the line that -- the invoicing requirements follow the product down to the hands of the retailer and from thereon, the protection is in the label, I think there's more difficulty.

turn.speaker: hugo_l_black
turn.label: Justice Hugo L. Black
turn.text: Which one do you think needs protection the most, a fur merchant or the individual that buys the fur from the fur merchant?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Well, there was a great deal of talk in these congressional hearings suggesting that the consumer needs information, needs facts, needs to avoid the glamorized description of fur product that seems to have been pervading the fur industry.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Horne, If I -- I apologize for asking so many questions, but I would like to ask you the same question I asked Mr. Friedman about the term "commercial transaction" or as you say, “commercially.”

I'd like to know if there's anything in the record or in the cases that indicate that that term is limited to -- to the wholesale trade or -- or whether it's applied equally to or at times to -- to the retail trade.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: No, Mr. Chief Justice.
There isn't a word in the reports or in the legislative history.
There is nothing in the record in this case.
There is one sidelight in which -- which maybe at some interest to you in the legislative history and neither is this.

The -- the term "dealing commercially" was used at another point, in an earlier stage of the -- the bill to designate -- it -- they said in Section 3 (d) of H.R. 3734 as reported in the 80th Congress.
That a person dealing commercially, if he has reason to believe that the label has come to him as wrong, may substitute another label.
That's the only other place in the history that I found dealing commercially is used.
Obviously there, it has to mean the wholesaler, the jobber, the retailer, because they're the only ones that are interested in looking at the label and substituting or correcting it.
The consumer certainly is not interested in substituting --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Could I ask you a collective question?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Certainly.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Under the Act now, construe this, you would have -- you'll have to furnish a label to the retailer, the same -- the same information with the invoice as the Government says.
We should also appreciate that.
What practical difference does it make, well if you'll have to furnish two pieces of label?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: From a practical standpoint and I'm speculating now, I must admit this isn't in the record.
Was -- it wasn't raised.

From the practical standpoint, the fur buyer, the head of the department can, before they open the door, go down to the line of garments and police the tags, and make certain that all of the tags or labels of -- are in proper order.

When the door is opened and the sale starts, and they have two or three dozen salesclerks to -- selling the products, it becomes a different matter watching every say -- it's just -- it's physically impossible to watch every sales slip that each clerk makes out to make certain that it touches on each of the six statutory elements.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Well, that's still what we have to label on, the label didn't have what you're reserving serving to a cease-and-desist order or --

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: -- proceeding -- better understanding the cease-and-desist order, so I don't see what the account of furnishing in the business with -- (Inaudible) except that is a laborer copying out from the label.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Well, there, it's more than the physical effort of copying.
It's a matter of checking to make certain that each clerk has copied correctly and that isn't always feasible.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: But it wasn't a proper case (Inaudible)
You keep copies --

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: We are --

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: You keep copies of your labels?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Not of the labels, Your Honor.
I don't believe they do.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Why wouldn't the invoice set the mere protection to you as well as to the public?
You'd have a copy of the invoice, a fellow allowed to label, you wouldn't have a copy of anything.
He could say, “Well, the saleslady is telling me it was a tissue and it turns out to be red.
She was playing, and you would say, "Oh no, this is not the coat," or something like that?
Well, if you had an invoice, which -- which described on a letter, your got in your invoice copy and you'd say, "Well, here's the invoice copy.
This shows what we gave you.
Here's your signature on it."
Looks like it protects you.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Well, it might.
But on the other hand -- well, I would suggest that that gets into an area in which the Federal Trade Commission has no function.
That's the local controversy in the Federal Trade Commission.
The -- the Fur Products Labeling Act is a disclosure act, and the Federal Trade Commission polices the disclosure, the completeness of the disclosure all through process.
But if --

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Well, I grant you a --

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: If a controversy arises at -- at the local level as in a merchant and his customer, it's going to be answered by the store's practices.

turn.speaker: charles_e_whittaker
turn.label: Justice Charles E. Whittaker
turn.text: I grant you, the Trade Act is aimed to the protection of the public and not protection to your bookkeeping, but you were trying to answer Justice Harlan as why you objected to this than a mere physical labor because of your clerks and I was just wondering why you and me in favor of it is going to go into the merits of it.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Well, if Your Honor please, we are objecting at this point because if there's a cease-and-desist order on us, we are exposed to future contempt or penalty proceedings if somebody makes another mistake.
And the lesser of that exposure we have, the happier the store will be.
That isn't to say that there hasn't been -- there -- I'm told that there has been a radical revision of all their procedures, I mentioned we made at the advertising.
That's all been changed.

That's in the cease-and-desist order, and their other procedures have been radically changed to try to bring them in the line, but there are limits to how far you can go with personnel and how much you can get out off them.
Now, you -- someone asked me a question a moment ago whether we'd be prosecuted for typographical error.
One of the elements on -- on the invoice in which we were found deficient is that the sales slip says Mandel Brothers and doesn't say -- the state of Madison to Chicago, Illinois.
The store had been there for more than 50 years and --

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Can you give the address?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: And -- we can give the address.
An attempt was made but the Commission didn't go along with it, speaking of technicalities.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Well, that's (Voice Overlap) --

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: The labels --

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Doesn't that indicate that they wouldn't go along with just their clerical errors.
They would say, “Well, Mr. Mandel, you didn't have this as a practice.
This was not your instructions to your clerk, to leave this out.
The clerk just (Inaudible) she's in a big hurry and you get the customer out of the store and I'm thinking now then failed to do it.
She made an error.
She failed to put down a petition.
They wouldn't enjoin a little -- a thing -- purely clerical error, would they?
I mean, they were the basic case on that.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Well, again, all I can say is they did.
That was while the deficiencies pointed out.
I know the deficiencies --

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: But at least they are instructions of the Mandel Brothers to their clerks rather than a clerical error of the clerk.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: No, they say of -- as a printed form, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: I know, but the filling in part, the part that you fill in.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Well, certainly, but we can instruct all day long and hope that the clerk will grasp it and we'll fill in all the required elements.

turn.speaker: tom_c_clark
turn.label: Justice Tom C. Clark
turn.text: Did you instruct them to give paying all six?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: That isn't in the record.
I assume that they have.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, isn't it your -- isn't it your position that you didn't instruct them to do anything so far as this invoice is concerned because you didn't believe you're obliged to under the law.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Oh no, Mr. Chief Justice.
Here's what happened.
The investigator from the Federal Trade Commission came in, in September of 1952, one month after the Act became effective to look over what they were doing.
Mandel Brothers was there as it had been, previously, giving these sales slips, such as are set forth in the record here.
There are fifteen or twenty of those things in -- in the record below.

The investigator went through the books and took samples of the sales slips, which they had been given -- giving and checked them to see if they were in conformity with the requirements of that new act.
He looked at the labels on the fur garments, checked them to see if they were in conformity with the new requirements.
He found some mistakes.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: You say that was within two months of the -- of the Act going onto effect in 1952?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: The Act gone into effect in -- in August of 1952 and if I remember correctly, the investigator was there in September of 1952.
He came back in October of 1954 --

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: -- for another inspection.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: And for whatever its worth, he found a great many fewer errors at the 1954 inspection.
And furthermore, for whatever it's worth, he -- it's in the record.
He says nothing -- there was no communication after the first inspection as to what -- whether they were doing anything wrong or what they were doing wrong.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I'm afraid Mr. Horne, I -- I totally misconceived what's your position is.
I thought your position in this case was that you are not obliged to have any -- any of this material on the invoice or sales tags or whatever we choose to call it.
And that you therefore -- therefore, you could not be ordered to cease-and-desist because the statute didn't require you to put it on.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Our position is that irrespective of whether these sales slips were within or without the -- whether they did or did not have all six elements.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: That that isn't -- the question here -- the question -- our position is that whether they did or didn't, it was gratuitous so far as the Act is concerned, the giving of this.
It has nothing to do with the Act.
The Act doesn't say that the retailer has to give the invoice.
The Act requires invoicing of furs from the raw pelt down to manufacturer.
The Act requires the labeling of fur products from the time they are manufactured until they reach the end to the consumer.
In addition, there is this further requirement, which is the issue before us.
It says "invoice fur product."
Now, the extent of that requirement, of invoicing fur product, whether or not these invoices we gave were good or bad.
The extent of that requirement of invoicing fur products is -- is the question here and that depends on what the definition means.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: If he doesn't --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: -- what is your position that -- is it your position that the law does or does not require the retailer to give an invoice, which will include this information?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Our position is that the law does not extend to requiring a statutorily detailed invoice from the retailer to the consumer.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, now, does it require any kind of an invoice?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: No -- no, Your Honor.
It will require -- the only requirement of an invoice is the statutorily detailed invoice.
There's no other involved.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: In the statute.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: And -- and you claim that's not applicable to you because you're a retailer?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Then why --

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Well --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Why do you say that you're -- you're conforming to it and it was only some slight deviations that they found in your invoices.
Is that essential to the case if you don't have to -- have to comply with the -- the invoice portion at all?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: If we don't have to comply, no, Your Honor.
But we had to file both steps in the case.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right, but then --

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Well, we have only the one step here.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: All right.
Then if you do have to comply, then the only question we have to determine is whether all of those things are included on your invoice, isn't that right?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: That's true, and I think that in -- in the present posture of the case, we can't deny that there was a finding and -- unreversed finding that some of them were not included --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: -- if they are subject to the statutory requirement of invoices.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: But our position is that your retailer to the consumer transaction has its complete and adequate protection in the requirement of a label.
The label has the same information, the Commission itself in its opinion twice, said, the clerk can copy from the -- from the label on the invoice.
And as -- as a further point, said that the -- the information required for the invoice is the same that's required for the label.
There's no -- there's no doubt about it.
It's a duplication.

turn.speaker: felix_frankfurter
turn.label: Justice Felix Frankfurter
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: And -- and --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.
In --

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: -- we -- our position is that the label is the thing that reaches the consumer and it has to be on the garment, on -- when she examines it or if she considers it and it has to stay on the garment until it's delivered into her hands.
But your invoice, what good does it do?
It doesn't -- except to -- for local bookkeeping reasons.
It's prepared after your sale has been consummated.
She doesn't see that until after she -- she takes the fur --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: -- coat home and unpacks it.

And as to the suggesting that they may lose or throw away the tag, I think it imputes absurdity federal legislation to say that it requires giving a consumer the same information on each of two pieces of paper, of course you'd like to lose one.

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: What -- what has the Commission been doing administrating, or in perspective (Inaudible) they have been requiring (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: The Commission is --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Or it's not your interest.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: I do know.
They have been after practically every fur dealer in the country, on and -- on the whole thing.
We -- we can't decide the basic.
That they think the position that's --

turn.speaker: john_m_harlan2
turn.label: Justice John M. Harlan
turn.text: Construe it that way themselves.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Yes.
Yes, Your Honor.
But we -- we don't feel that it -- this is the first case in which that issue has been litigated.
We don't feel that's a long embedded practice.
Moreover, the thing was before Congress through three sessions.
The Commission wrote six letters of comment to the congressional committees describing the bill.
And in every case, the Commission said “Just two requirement.”
So the bill required invoice first and label fur product.
They never mentioned this other -- in any of the letters.
So that that fur -- that interpretation apparently was established after the Act got into the hands of Commission for administration.
There's just one other feature of the legislative history I would like to touch on briefly.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Mr. Horne, your time is about up, but we have taken so much of your time asking -- asking questions.
I think you're entitled with few minutes of -- uninterrupted argument and I'm going to give you five minutes extra to --

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: State what you want to say.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: I am glad to have to have the question because it indicates --

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Well, I (Voice Overlap) -- if you would like to sum up your argument and put it in perspective way.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Well, for one thing on the -- the invoicing question, it depends altogether on the interpretation of this term "invoice".
I -- short -- I used a shorthand reference to it a moment ago or -- or other commercially dealing person, purchaser, consignee, factor, bailee or other commercially dealing person.

And I would like to point out just briefly the parallel between the language, that language and the language that the Court had before it in United States versus Standard Brewery, that's cited in our brief.
The statute prohibited use of food products in the manufacture or production of beer, wine, or other intoxicating liquor.
And the Court held that -- or other intoxicating liquor referred back and modified beer and wine and it had to be intoxicating beer before it was in that prohibition.
Similarly, we say that this clause, commercially dealing person, goes back and modifies that -- enumeration of the persons who are concerned with the handling of furs.

Now, you'll want to know, I think, why we say that it's reasonable that Congress should have required the invoicing of fur products from the manufacturer to the retailer and not require it from the retailer to the -- to the consumer.
The reason for that, it seems to us, is found in the fact that you're intervening persons, your wholesaler, your jobber or your retailer.
Each one is responsible for seeing that the garment has a proper label on it before it goes forward from him.

If the wholesaler, the jobber, the retailer has a statutory invoice, a statutorily detailed invoice, he has something against which he can check the correctness of the invoice, of the label for which he is responsible.
But the consumer doesn't have any responsibility to pass -- pass it on to anybody.
And the consumer had -- does have the full protection of the required statutory label.

There was a mention of the testimony in the hearings in the 80th Congress, where this whole legislation originated, the fur dealers and processors and manufacturers were about the only witnesses that were in there, except to -- to irrelevant groups that were barred.
They were opposing the legislation.
They were opposing any legislation.
They were opposing labeling.
When they advocated invoicing to be observed, they didn't advocate invoicing but we touched them.
They advocated invoicing by somebody else.
The -- at the outset of those hearings, I have been testimony by a representative from the Federal Trade Commission who had recommended labeling as the remedy for the bills of the business.

At the close of those hearings and how it's in the 80th, the sponsor of the bill, Congressman O'Hara, called as if -- he's the representative, if I could stand and ask if he could add anything to testimony.
He reaffirmed his previous advocacy of labeling then he turned to the suggestion of invoicing as being -- as against labeling.
And he said, “Labeling would be a more effective remedy than invoicing because the label gives the customer facts before the -- before she makes her choice.
The invoice comes after."
Then he said it would be like locking the barn door after the horse is stolen.
He also went on the comment, "There is no burden on the manufacturer's invoice, but there is a burden on the retailer to give an invoice at the time to every sale."

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Mr. Horne, on the second aspect of this case, are you and the Government now on agreement as to the form of the order?

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: Well, what they suggest would be an improvement on what the Commission did, but it would still leave us in the position where we're subject to a cease-and-desist order, and if we do violate, it will be a penalty the first time and not the second time until your cease-and-desist order put you -- says that you will --

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: You'd be violating one of the three respects in which you have -- have been talking.

turn.speaker: samuel_h_horne
turn.label: Mr. Samuel H. Horne
turn.text: If we -- if one of the three respects in which we -- we were exonerated.
I thank you.

turn.speaker: earl_warren
turn.label: Chief Justice Earl Warren
turn.text: Very well.
